abstract: <jats:p>The genus<jats:italic>Antispila</jats:italic>Hübner, [1825] is newly recorded from mainland China.<jats:italic>Antispila sinensis</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold>, the first formally named Heliozelidae species in mainland China, is described. The host plant of the new species,<jats:italic>Cornus walteri</jats:italic>Wangerin (Cornaceae), is widespread through east Asia and is used as a shade tree in city parks in Jinan City, where the moth causes damage to foliage. Morphological and molecular analyses distinguish<jats:italic>A. sinensis</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold>from its close relatives. The adult, pupa, larva, host plant, leaf-mines, and the shield of the new species are illustrated, as are male and female genitalia, venation, and larval chaetotaxy. DNA barcodes of the new species are also provided.</jats:p>
title: First report of the leaf-mining genus Antispila Hübner, [1825] from mainland China, with the description of a new species feeding on Cornus (Lepidoptera, Heliozelidae)

reference.author: Denis
reference.journal-title: Ankündung eines systematischen Werkes von den Schmetterlingen der Wienergegend.
